abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Lynch syndrome (LS; HNPCC) patients carry heterozygous pathogenic germline variants in mismatch repair (MMR) genes, which have also been shown to play an important role in meiosis. Therefore, it was hypothesized, that LS might be associated with a higher risk for premature ovarian failure (POF) or earlier menopause. Data on medical gynaecological history, cancer diagnoses and therapy were collected from 167 female LS patients and compared to a population-based control cohort. There was no difference between the age of menopause in patients compared to controls and no evidence for a higher risk of POF in LS patients. However, around one third (35%) of the probands have already had premenopausal cancer and mostly cancer-related treatment affecting fertility before the age of 45 years. Therefore, childbearing time might still be limited in these patients, especially due to the premenopausal cancer risk. LS patients should be informed in time about the elevated premenopausal cancer risks and the possible impact on family planning. This is particularly relevant since the average childbearing age has increased during the last decades.</jats:p>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: This study was performed in line with the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki. Approval was granted in 2009 by the Ethics Committee of the University of Bonn, Germany (project no. 115/09).

assertion.value: The authors declare no competing interests.

title: High amount of fertility reducing tumors and procedures, but no evidence for premature ovarian failure in female Lynch syndrome patients
